markdownRemark.html:
Holiday Break = Monopoly (Logically) 😂

Ahhh, it’s that time of year again - a break from work, and some time with the family.

For my family at least, that sometimes means playing Monopoly! (What other time of year do you have 4+ hours to spend duking it out with one of the world’s most loved1 games?)

So, anyway, my brother had snagged both the purples (Mediterranean and Baltic) and the light blues (, and Connecticut) . When a player owns both of these adjacent monopolies, we cherishingly call that player the ‘slum lord’). My girlfriend ended up with the greens and blues, what we call the ‘high roller’ properties. I of course, thought she had the better advantage of winning. But as the game went on, we realized just how high maintenance (the properties, not my girlfriend 😂) those expensive are. First, they cost a fortune to buy, and at $200 dollars per house. In addition, Boardwalk and Park Place have the added fact that they are only a 2 property set.

In the end, my girlfriend was one of the first players to go out, while my brother lasted as 2nd place in the game (I actually ended up winning due to massive luck with the purple properties (Virginia, States, and St. Charles Place))

So, now the question: was our intuition with higher or lower prof? Or is it true that some properties and property groups have an inherently better profit margin?

Turns out, it couldn’t be more true!

Raw Return

I calculated the percent return on investment (ROI) as follows:

a2+b2=c2a^2 + b^2 = c^2a2+b2=c2 %ROI = \\frac{(total price per property + the cost of building to hotel)}{rent cost of property with hotel} \times 100

I calculated and plotted the ROI for 1,2, and 3 ‘lands’ on a property:

If you’re a table kind of person, here’s all the same data in a table:

This analysis of the expected return on a property show us that the light blue properties are the best investment in terms of expected return. However, we need to consider locations on the board to complete our analysis.

Spatial Considerations

First, it’s important to note the roll probability of two dice.

Yes, landing on Community Chest from jail is most likely with a roll of 7 at 16.667% from a two sided dice roll, but Tennessee, St. James, and New York Avenue all are close in following probabilities at 13.889%, 13.889%, and 11.111%, for an overwhelming net of 38.889% chance of a landing on an orange property from a single role from jail.

Sources

  • Tabulated Card Data (I redacted the UK version titles in the names on my own chart, keeping only the US versions): http://www.falstad.com/monopoly.html
  • Converting HTML tag to CSV with: http://convertcsv.com/html-table-to-csv.htm
  • Probabilities for 6 sided dice: http://alumnus.caltech.edu/~leif/FRP/probability.html

    • Further References and Reading

    Truman Collins already did a massive probability analysis of Monopoly in his blog in 2005..

    Jim Slater, the famous English bank businessman, provides a breakdown of the expected returns of some of the monopolies (and independently matches what was found by me, I’ll be proud to admit! 😄) in the fourth episode of “The Mayfair Set” documentaries by Adam Curtis, (though in the video he is referring to the English names of the properties - helpful that he still mentions the colors 😂).

    Footnotes

    1. As of 2018, Monopoly has been licensed in more than 103 countries and printed in more than thirty-seven languages!!!
